results.title: Find the one that's different
results.creator_credit: University of Wisconsin and Bill Wadsmith
results.brief_description: Designed to help teachers identify and work effectively with students who have learning disabilities. Provides examples of the frustration and failure of children whose problems are not recognised, as well as the remarkable success of children whose behavioural patterns are diagnosed as a learning disability and are dealt with appropriately. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.title: Find out, talk about
results.creator_credit: Victorian Film Corporation, Kent Chadwick and Don McLennan
results.brief_description: Looks at the world of six first generation Australian children from different national backgrounds who have formed genuine friendships across cultural boundaries. The film suggests that at this level many of the prejudices that have existed in the Australian community are being broken down and the concept of a genuine multicultural society is quite possibly becoming a reality. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Financing the wool clip
results.brief_description: A documentary in two parts. Part one: is mainly about numbers of sheep shawn per year, how many shearers needed, plus quantities of food and financing of wages. The equipment needed from sheep dip, shearing scissors, wire fencing for rabbit control to corrugated iron for housing etc. Part two: deals with shipping and banking such as Letters of Credit from English banks and Bill of Lading and insurance.

results.title: Finally destroy us
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Kalin’s short video works function both as visual poems and as alternative music videos. With their astute conjunctions of image, music and text, these tapes respond to issues of sexuality and human interaction in the 1990s, more than a decade into the AIDS crisis. In finally destroy us, Kalin uses found film footage, home movies, and haunting pop music (Annie Lenox singing Cole Porter) to poignantly recall moments of love, shared and lost. The title is taken from Virginia Woolf: ‘But these meetings, these partings, finally destroy us’.

results.title: Finale
results.creator_credit: Triangle Productions, Theodora Olembert, Robert Bas and Michael Darlow
results.brief_description: A nostalgic look at the Marlborough Music Hall in North London. It was demolished and we see this being done interspersed with photographs of the famous music hall stars who played there and their special acts.

results.title: Final fantasy: the spirits within
results.creator_credit: Chris Lee, Square Co, Columbia Pictures, Jun Aida, Akio Sakai, Hiroonobu Sakaguchi and Motonori Sakakibara
results.brief_description: Based on the Final Fantasy video games, this computer animated feature presents an apocalyptic vision of earth in the not too distant future. The year is 2069; planet earth has now been rendered uninhabitable due to an invasion by a race of phantom like extraterrestrials. What’s left of the human race has now retreated into outer space as they wait and plan a counter-attack against the vicious aliens. Brilliant young scientist Dr. Aki Ross (Ming-Na), is plagued with prophetic dreams about earth’s future. In an attempt to combat the aliens and to find the cure to the deadly ‘alien spirits’ that have infected her body, she joins forces with a prestigious military squad called Deep Eyes. Working with a team of international animators, the filmmakers have managed to create a spectacular if not bleak vision of the future. This is also the first time that animators have attempted to create photo-realistic human characters, meticulously animating every small detail, right down to the movement of each strand of hair on a characters head. Cast voices include Alec Baldwin, James Woods, Donald Sutherland, Ving Rhames and Steve Buscemi.

results.title: Final Cut
results.creator_credit: Segma Limited, Dominic Anciano and Ray Burdis
results.brief_description: Film makers Dominic Anciano and Ray Burdis have created an original rumination on friendship which blurs the line between documentary and fiction. Jude Law is a recently deceased film maker whose latest film is screened to his grieving family and friends on the day of his funeral. The group is shocked to find that over the last year Jude has in fact been filming them, using hidden cameras to record their most private moments and guilty secrets. Embarrassment gradually turns to fear as the film peels back the layers of their lives, each more treacherous than the last. With liberal use of improvisation and a tour-de-force performance from Ray Winstone, ‘Final Cut’ is a contemporary exploration of morality, mortality and the power of the recorded image. Cast also includes Sadie Frost, Dominic Anciano and Ray Burdis.

results.title: fin du jour
results.creator_credit: Filmsonar a Epinay, Regina Film and Julien Duvivier
results.brief_description:
This comedy peeks in at the lives and relationships between elderly thespians living in an actors’ retirement home. The home is almost bankrupt and so the actors must support themselves. The residents include a faded sex symbol, an intellectual actor who kept a great distance between himself and the audience, and a depressed thespian who tries to conceal the fact that he was only an understudy.

Credits: Director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Charles Spaak, Julien Duvivier ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Michel Simon, Madeleine Ozeray, Victor Francen, Gabrielle Dorziat, Sylvie.

results.title: Films by Harry Smith = Harry Smith: early abstractions
results.brief_description: Harry Smith, filmmaker, painter, anthropologist, linguist, and more, was a unique artist who believed in the interconnectedness of human existence. An anthropology student who became involved in the early incarnation of the counter-culture movement, Smith is credited with developing ingenious methods of animation, collage techniques, and hand-painting directly onto film. No 1: Hand drawn animation of shapes - the history of the geologic period depicted in three minutes. No 2: Geometric shapes, circles, squares, and dirty dots morph to the sounds of the Beatles’ rocking tune “I wanna hold your hand”. No 3: Batiked animation made up of a complex interlocking of squares and oblongs, criss-crossings, leaping on and off the screen. No 4: Black and white abstractions of dots and grillwork, this short work evokes an urban night on the town. No 5: “III Circular tensions” This colour abstraction pays homage to fellow animator Oskar Fischinger. No 6: Optically printed Pythagoreanism in four movements supported on squares, circles, grillwork, and triangles. No 10: An exposition of Buddhism and the Kaballa in the form of a collage.
